00052 /************************* NETWORK MANIFEST CONSTANT SANITY CHECKS ****************************/
00053 #if !defined(ACCESS_POINT) && !defined(RANGE_EXTENDER) && !defined(END_DEVICE)
00054 #error ERROR: No SimpliciTI device type defined
00055 #endif
00056 
00057 #if defined(END_DEVICE) && !defined(RX_POLLS)
00058 #define RX_USER
00059 #endif
00060 
00061 #ifndef MAX_HOPS
00062 #define MAX_HOPS  3
00063 #elif MAX_HOPS > 4
00064 #error ERROR: MAX_HOPS must be 4 or fewer
00065 #endif
00066 
00067 #ifndef MAX_APP_PAYLOAD
00068 #error ERROR: MAX_APP_PAYLOAD must be defined
00069 #endif
00070 
00071 #if ( MAX_PAYLOAD < MAX_FREQ_APP_FRAME )
00072 #error ERROR: Application payload size too small for Frequency frame
00073 #endif
00074 
00075 #if ( MAX_PAYLOAD < MAX_JOIN_APP_FRAME )
00076 #error ERROR: Application payload size too small for Join frame
00077 #endif
00078 
00079 #if ( MAX_PAYLOAD < MAX_LINK_APP_FRAME )
00080 #error ERROR: Application payload size too small for Link frame
00081 #endif
00082 
00083 #if ( MAX_PAYLOAD < MAX_MGMT_APP_FRAME )
00084 #error ERROR: Application payload size too small for Management frame
00085 #endif
00086 
00087 #if ( MAX_PAYLOAD < MAX_SEC_APP_FRAME )
00088 #error ERROR: Application payload size too small for Security frame
00089 #endif
00090 
00091 #if ( MAX_PAYLOAD < MAX_PING_APP_FRAME )
00092 #error ERROR: Application payload size too small for Ping frame
00093 #endif
00094 
00095 #if NWK_FREQ_TBL_SIZE < 1
00096 #error ERROR: NWK_FREQ_TBL_SIZE must be > 0
00097 #endif
00098 
00099 /************************* END NETWORK MANIFEST CONSTANT SANITY CHECKS ************************/
00100 
00101 /******************************************************************************
00102  * CONSTANTS AND DEFINES
00103  */
00104 #define SYS_NUM_CONNECTIONS   (NUM_CONNECTIONS+1)
00105 
00106 /* Increment this if the persistentContext_t structure is changed. It will help
00107  * detect the upgrade context: any saved values will have a version with a
00108  * lower number.
00109  */
00110 #define  CONNTABLEINFO_STRUCTURE_VERSION   1
00111 
00112 #define  SIZEOF_NV_OBJ   sizeof(sPersistInfo)
00113 
00114 /******************************************************************************
00115  * TYPEDEFS
00116  */
00117 /* This structure aggregates eveything necessary to save if we want to restore
00118  * the connection information later.
00119  */
00120 typedef struct
00121 {
00122   const uint8_t    structureVersion; /* to dectect upgrades... */
00123         uint8_t    numConnections;   /* count includes the UUD port/link ID */
00124 /* The next two are used to detect overlapping port assignments. When _sending_ a
00125  * link frame the local port is assigned from the top down. When sending a _reply_
00126  * the assignment is bottom up. Overlapping assignments are rejected. That said it
00127  * is extremely unlikely that this will ever happen. If it does the test implemented
00128  * here is overly cautious (it will reject assignments when it needn't). But we leave
00129  * it that way on the assumption that it will never happen anyway.
00130  */
00131         uint8_t    curNextLinkPort;
00132         uint8_t    curMaxReplyPort;
00133         linkID_t   nextLinkID;
00134 #ifdef ACCESS_POINT
00135         sfInfo_t   sSandFContext;
00136 #endif
00137 /* Connection table entries last... */
00138         connInfo_t connStruct[SYS_NUM_CONNECTIONS];
00139 } persistentContext_t;
00140 
00141 /******************************************************************************
00142  * LOCAL VARIABLES
00143  */
00144 
00145 /* This will be overwritten if we restore the structure from NV for example.
00146  * Note that restoring will not permit overwriting the version element as it
00147  * is declared 'const'.
00148  */
00149 static persistentContext_t sPersistInfo = {CONNTABLEINFO_STRUCTURE_VERSION};
00150 
00151 /******************************************************************************
00152  * LOCAL FUNCTIONS
00153  */
00154 static uint8_t map_lid2idx(linkID_t, uint8_t *);
00155 static void    initializeConnection(connInfo_t *);
00156 
00157 /******************************************************************************
00158  * GLOBAL VARIABLES
00159  */
00160 
00161 /******************************************************************************
00162  * GLOBAL FUNCTIONS
00163  */
00164 
00165 /******************************************************************************
00166  * @fn          nwk_nwkInit
00167  *
00168  * @brief       Initialize NWK conext.
00169  *
00170  * input parameters
00171  *
00172  * output parameters
00173  *
00174  * @return   Status of operation.
00175  */
00176 smplStatus_t nwk_nwkInit(uint8_t (*f)(linkID_t))
00177 {
00178   /* Truly ugly initialization because CCE won't initialize properly. Must
00179    * skip first const element. Yuk.
00180    */
00181   memset((((uint8_t *)&sPersistInfo)+1), 0x0, (sizeof(sPersistInfo)-1));
00182   /* OK. The zeroed elements are set. Now go back and do fixups...  */
00183 
00184   sPersistInfo.numConnections   = SYS_NUM_CONNECTIONS;
00185   sPersistInfo.curNextLinkPort  = SMPL_PORT_USER_MAX;
00186   sPersistInfo.curMaxReplyPort  = PORT_BASE_NUMBER;
00187   sPersistInfo.nextLinkID       = 1;
00188 
00189   /* initialize globals */
00190   nwk_globalsInit();
00191 
00192   /* initialize frame processing */
00193   nwk_frameInit(f);
00194 
00195   /* initialize queue manager */
00196   nwk_QInit();
00197         
00198   /* initialize each network application. */
00199   nwk_freqInit();
00200   nwk_pingInit();
00201   nwk_joinInit(f);
00202   nwk_mgmtInit();
00203   nwk_linkInit();
00204   nwk_securityInit();
00205 
00206   /* set up the last connection as the broadcast port mapped to the broadcast Link ID */
00207   if (CONNSTATE_FREE == sPersistInfo.connStruct[NUM_CONNECTIONS].connState)
00208   {
00209     sPersistInfo.connStruct[NUM_CONNECTIONS].connState   = CONNSTATE_CONNECTED;
00210     sPersistInfo.connStruct[NUM_CONNECTIONS].hops2target = MAX_HOPS;
00211     sPersistInfo.connStruct[NUM_CONNECTIONS].portRx      = SMPL_PORT_USER_BCAST;
00212     sPersistInfo.connStruct[NUM_CONNECTIONS].portTx      = SMPL_PORT_USER_BCAST;
00213     sPersistInfo.connStruct[NUM_CONNECTIONS].thisLinkID  = SMPL_LINKID_USER_UUD;
00214     /* set peer address to broadcast so it is used when Application sends to the broadcast Link ID */
00215     memcpy(sPersistInfo.connStruct[NUM_CONNECTIONS].peerAddr, nwk_getBCastAddress(), NET_ADDR_SIZE);
00216   }
00217 
00218   return SMPL_SUCCESS;
00219 }
00220 
00221 /******************************************************************************
00222  * @fn          nwk_getNextConnection
00223  *
00224  * @brief       Return the next free connection structure if on is available.
00225  *
00226  * input parameters
00227  *
00228  * output parameters
00229  *      The returned structure has the Rx port number populated based on the
00230  *      free strucure found. This is the port queried when the app wants to
00231  *      do a receive.
00232  *
00233  * @return   pointer to the new connInfo_t structure. NULL if there is
00234  *           no room in connection structure array.
00235  */
00236 connInfo_t *nwk_getNextConnection()
00237 {
00238   uint8_t  i;
00239 
00240   for (i=0; i<SYS_NUM_CONNECTIONS; ++i)
00241   {
00242     if (sPersistInfo.connStruct[i].connState == CONNSTATE_CONNECTED)
00243     {
00244       continue;
00245     }
00246     break;
00247   }
00248 
00249   if (SYS_NUM_CONNECTIONS == i)
00250   {
00251     return (connInfo_t *)0;
00252   }
00253 
00254   initializeConnection(&sPersistInfo.connStruct[i]);
00255 
00256   return &sPersistInfo.connStruct[i];
00257 }
00258 
00259 /************************************************************************************
00260  * @fn          initializeConnection
00261  *
00262  * @brief       Initialize some elements of a Connection table entry.
00263  *
00264  * input parameters
00265  * @param   pCInfo  - pointer to Connection Table entry to initialize. The file
00266  *                    scope variable holding the next link ID value is also updated.
00267  *
00268  * output parameters
00269  * @param   pCInfo  - certain elements are set to specific values.
00270  *
00271  *
00272  * @return   void
00273  */
00274 static void initializeConnection(connInfo_t *pCInfo)
00275 {
00276   linkID_t *locLID = &sPersistInfo.nextLinkID;
00277   uint8_t   tmp;
00278 
00279     /* this element will be populated during the exchange with the peer. */
00280   pCInfo->portTx = 0;
00281 
00282   pCInfo->connState  =  CONNSTATE_CONNECTED;
00283   pCInfo->thisLinkID = *locLID;
00284 
00285   /* Generate the next Link ID. This isn't foolproof. If the count wraps
00286    * we can end up with confusing duplicates. We can protect aginst using
00287    * one that is already in use but we can't protect against a stale Link ID
00288    * remembered by an application that doesn't know its connection has been
00289    * torn down. The test for 0 will hopefully never be true (indicating a wrap).
00290    */
00291   (*locLID)++;
00292 
00293   while (!*locLID || (*locLID == SMPL_LINKID_USER_UUD) || map_lid2idx(*locLID, &tmp))
00294   {
00295     (*locLID)++;
00296   }
00297 
00298   return;
00299 }
00300 
00301 
00302 /******************************************************************************
00303  * @fn          nwk_freeConnection
00304  *
00305  * @brief       Return the connection structure to the free pool. Currently
00306  *              this routine is only called when a link freame is sent and
00307  *              no reply is received so the freeing steps are pretty simple.
00308  *              But eventually this will be more complex so this place-holder
00309  *              is introduced.
00310  *
00311  * input parameters
00312  * @param   pCInfo    - pointer to entry to be freed
00313  *
00314  * output parameters
00315  *
00316  * @return   None.
00317  */
00318 void nwk_freeConnection(connInfo_t *pCInfo)
00319 {
00320 #if NUM_CONNECTIONS > 0
00321   pCInfo->connState = CONNSTATE_FREE;
00322 #endif
00323 }
00324 
00325 /******************************************************************************
00326  * @fn          nwk_getConnInfo
00327  *
00328  * @brief       Return the connection info structure to which the input Link ID maps.
00329  *
00330  * input parameters
00331  * @param   port    - port for which mapping desired
00332  *
00333  * output parameters
00334  *
00335  * @return   pointer to connInfo_t structure found. NULL if no mapping
00336  *           found or entry not valid.
00337  */
00338 connInfo_t *nwk_getConnInfo(linkID_t linkID)
00339 {
00340   uint8_t idx, rc;
00341 
00342   rc = map_lid2idx(linkID, &idx);
00343 
00344   return (rc && (CONNSTATE_CONNECTED == sPersistInfo.connStruct[idx].connState)) ? &sPersistInfo.connStruct[idx] : (connInfo_t *)0;
00345 }
00346 
00347 /******************************************************************************
00348  * @fn          nwk_isLinkDuplicate
00349  *
00350  * @brief       Help determine if the link has already been established.. Defense
00351  *              against duplicate link frames. This file owns the data structure
00352  *              so the comparison is done here.
00353  *
00354  * input parameters
00355  * @param   addr       - pointer to address of linker in question
00356  * @param   remotePort - remote port number provided by linker
00357  *
00358  * output parameters
00359  *
00360  * @return   Returns pointer to connection entry if the address and remote Port
00361  *           match an existing entry, otherwise 0.
00362  */
00363 connInfo_t *nwk_isLinkDuplicate(uint8_t *addr, uint8_t remotePort)
00364 {
00365 #if NUM_CONNECTIONS > 0
00366   uint8_t       i;
00367   connInfo_t   *ptr = sPersistInfo.connStruct;
00368 
00369   for (i=0; i<NUM_CONNECTIONS; ++i,++ptr)
00370   {
00371     if (CONNSTATE_CONNECTED == ptr->connState)
00372     {
00373       if (!(memcmp(ptr->peerAddr, addr, NET_ADDR_SIZE)) &&
00374           (ptr->portTx == remotePort))
00375       {
00376         return ptr;
00377       }
00378     }
00379   }
00380 #endif
00381 
00382   return (connInfo_t *)NULL;
00383 }
00384 
00385 /******************************************************************************
00386  * @fn          nwk_findAddressMatch
00387  *
00388  * @brief       Used to look for an address match in the Connection table.
00389  *              Match is based on source address in frame.
00390  *
00391  * input parameters
00392  * @param   frame    - pointer to frame in question
00393  *
00394  * output parameters
00395  *
00396  * @return   Returns non-zero if a match is found, otherwise 0.
00397  */
00398 uint8_t nwk_findAddressMatch(mrfiPacket_t *frame)
00399 {
00400 #if NUM_CONNECTIONS > 0
00401   uint8_t       i;
00402   connInfo_t   *ptr = sPersistInfo.connStruct;
00403 
00404   for (i=0; i<NUM_CONNECTIONS; ++i,++ptr)
00405   {
00406 
00407     if (CONNSTATE_CONNECTED == ptr->connState)
00408     {
00409       if (!(memcmp(ptr->peerAddr, MRFI_P_SRC_ADDR(frame), NET_ADDR_SIZE)))
00410       {
00411         return 1;
00412       }
00413     }
00414   }
00415 #endif
00416 
00417   return 0;
00418 }
00419 
00420 #ifdef ACCESS_POINT
00421 /******************************************************************************
00422  * @fn          nwk_getSFInfoPtr
00423  *
00424  * @brief       Get pointer to store-and-forward information object kept in the
00425  *              NV object aggregate.
00426  *
00427  * input parameters
00428  *
00429  * output parameters
00430  *
00431  * @return   Returns pointer to the store-nad-forward object.
00432  */
00433 sfInfo_t *nwk_getSFInfoPtr(void)
00434 {
00435   return &sPersistInfo.sSandFContext;
00436 }
00437 
00438 #if defined(AP_IS_DATA_HUB)
00439 /***************************************************************************************
00440  * @fn          nwk_saveJoinedDevice
00441  *
00442  * @brief       Save the address of a joining device on the Connection Table expecting
00443  *              a Link frame to follow. Only for when AP is a data hub. We want to
00444  *              use the space already allocated for a connection able entry instead
00445  *              of having redundant arrays for alread-joined devices in the data hub
00446  *              case.
00447  *
00448  * input parameters
00449  * @param   frame  - pointer to frame containing address or joining device.
00450  *
00451  * output parameters
00452  *
00453  * @return   Returns non-zero if this is a new device and it is saved. Returns
00454  *           0 if device already there or there is no room in the Connection
00455  *           Table.
00456  */
00457 uint8_t nwk_saveJoinedDevice(mrfiPacket_t *frame)
00458 {
00459   uint8_t     i;
00460   connInfo_t *avail = 0;
00461   connInfo_t *ptr   = sPersistInfo.connStruct;
00462 
00463   for (i=0; i<NUM_CONNECTIONS; ++i, ++ptr)
00464   {
00465     if ((ptr->connState == CONNSTATE_CONNECTED) || (ptr->connState == CONNSTATE_JOINED))
00466     {
00467       if (!memcmp(ptr->peerAddr, MRFI_P_SRC_ADDR(frame), NET_ADDR_SIZE))
00468       {
00469         return 0;
00470       }
00471     }
00472     else
00473     {
00474       avail = ptr;
00475     }
00476   }
00477 
00478   if (!avail)
00479   {
00480     return 0;
00481   }
00482 
00483   avail->connState = CONNSTATE_JOINED;
00484   memcpy(avail->peerAddr, MRFI_P_SRC_ADDR(frame), NET_ADDR_SIZE);
00485 
00486   return 1;
00487 }
00488 
00489 /***********************************************************************************
00490  * @fn          nwk_findAlreadyJoined
00491  *
00492  * @brief       Used when AP is a data hub to look for an address match in the
00493  *              Connection table for a device that is already enterd in the joined
00494  *              state. This means that the Connection Table resource is already
00495  *              allocated so the link-listen doesn't have to do it again. Match is
00496  *              based on source address in frame. Thsi shoudl only be called from
00497  *              the Link-listen context during the link frame reply.
00498  *
00499  *              If found the Connection Table entry is initialized as if it were
00500  *              found using the nwk_getNextConnection() method.
00501  *
00502  * input parameters
00503  * @param   frame    - pointer to frame in question
00504  *
00505  * output parameters
00506  *
00507  * @return   Returns pointer to Connection Table entry if match is found, otherwise
00508  *           0. This call will only fail if the Connection Table was full when the
00509  *           device tried to join initially.
00510  */
00511 connInfo_t *nwk_findAlreadyJoined(mrfiPacket_t *frame)
00512 {
00513   uint8_t     i;
00514   connInfo_t *ptr = sPersistInfo.connStruct;
00515 
00516   for (i=0; i<NUM_CONNECTIONS; ++i,++ptr)
00517   {
00518     /* Look for an entry in the JOINED state */
00519     if (CONNSTATE_JOINED == ptr->connState)
00520     {
00521       /* Is this it? */
00522       if (!(memcmp(&ptr->peerAddr, MRFI_P_SRC_ADDR(frame), NET_ADDR_SIZE)))
00523       {
00524         /* Yes. Initilize tabel entry and return the pointer. */
00525         initializeConnection(ptr);
00526         return ptr;
00527       }
00528     }
00529   }
00530 
00531   /* Nothing found... */
00532   return (connInfo_t *)NULL;
00533 }
00534 #endif  /* AP_IS_DATA_HUB */
00535 #endif  /* ACCESS_POINT */
00536 
00537 /******************************************************************************
00538  * @fn          nwk_checkConnInfo
00539  *
00540  * @brief       Do a sanity/validity check on the connection info
00541  *
00542  * input parameters
00543  * @param   ptr     - pointer to a valid connection info structure to validate
00544  * @param   which   - Tx or Rx port checked
00545  *
00546  * output parameters
00547  *
00548  * @return   Status of operation.
00549  */
00550 smplStatus_t nwk_checkConnInfo(connInfo_t *ptr, uint8_t which)
00551 {
00552   uint8_t  port;
00553 
00554   /* make sure port isn't null and that the entry is active */
00555   port = (CHK_RX == which) ? ptr->portRx : ptr->portTx;
00556   if (!port || (CONNSTATE_FREE == ptr->connState))
00557   {
00558     return SMPL_BAD_PARAM;
00559   }
00560 
00561   /* validate port number */
00562   if (port < PORT_BASE_NUMBER)
00563   {
00564     return SMPL_BAD_PARAM;
00565   }
00566 
00567   return SMPL_SUCCESS;
00568 }
00569 
00570 /******************************************************************************
00571  * @fn          nwk_isConnectionValid
00572  *
00573  * @brief       Do a sanity/validity check on the frame target address by
00574  *              validating frame against connection info
00575  *
00576  * input parameters
00577  * @param   frame   - pointer to frame in question
00578  *
00579  * output parameters
00580  * @param   lid   - link ID of found connection
00581  *
00582  * @return   0 if connection specified in frame is not valid, otherwise non-zero.
00583  */
00584 uint8_t nwk_isConnectionValid(mrfiPacket_t *frame, linkID_t *lid)
00585 {
00586   uint8_t       i;
00587   connInfo_t   *ptr  = sPersistInfo.connStruct;
00588   uint8_t       port = GET_FROM_FRAME(MRFI_P_PAYLOAD(frame), F_PORT_OS);
00589 
00590   for (i=0; i<SYS_NUM_CONNECTIONS; ++i,++ptr)
00591   {
00592     if (CONNSTATE_CONNECTED == ptr->connState)
00593     {
00594       /* check port first since we're done if the port is the user bcast port. */
00595       if (port == ptr->portRx)
00596       {
00597         /* yep...ports match. */
00598         if ((SMPL_PORT_USER_BCAST == port) || !(memcmp(ptr->peerAddr, MRFI_P_SRC_ADDR(frame), NET_ADDR_SIZE)))
00599         {
00600           uint8_t rc = 1;
00601 
00602           /* we're done. */
00603           *lid = ptr->thisLinkID;
00604 #ifdef APP_AUTO_ACK
00605           /* can't ack the broadcast port... */
00606           if (!(SMPL_PORT_USER_BCAST == port))
00607           {
00608             if (GET_FROM_FRAME(MRFI_P_PAYLOAD(frame), F_ACK_REQ))
00609             {
00610               /* Ack requested. Send ack now */
00611               nwk_sendAckReply(frame, ptr->portTx);
00612             }
00613             else if (GET_FROM_FRAME(MRFI_P_PAYLOAD(frame), F_ACK_RPLY))
00614             {
00615               /* This is a reply. Signal that it was received by resetting the
00616                * saved transaction ID in the connection object if they match. The
00617                * main thread is polling this value. The setting here is in the
00618                * Rx ISR thread.
00619                */
00620               if (ptr->ackTID == GET_FROM_FRAME(MRFI_P_PAYLOAD(frame), F_TRACTID_OS))
00621               {
00622                 ptr->ackTID = 0;
00623               }
00624               /* This causes the frame to be dropped. All ack frames are
00625                * dropped.
00626                */
00627               rc = 0;
00628             }
00629           }
00630 #endif  /* APP_AUTO_ACK */
00631           /* Unconditionally kill the reply delay semaphore. This used to be done
00632            * unconditionally in the calling routine.
00633            */
00634           MRFI_PostKillSem();
00635           return rc;
00636         }
00637       }
00638     }
00639   }
00640 
00641   /* no matches */
00642   return 0;
00643 }
00644 
00645 /******************************************************************************
00646  * @fn          nwk_allocateLocalRxPort
00647  *
00648  * @brief       Allocate a local port on which to receive frames from a peer.
00649  *
00650  *              Allocation differs depending on whether the allocation is for
00651  *              a link reply frame or a link frame. In the former case we
00652  *              know the address of the peer so we can ensure allocating a
00653  *              unique port number for that address. The same port number can be
00654  *              used mulitple times for distinct peers. Allocations are done from
00655  *              the bottom of the namespace upward.
00656  *
00657  *              If allocation is for a link frame we do not yet know the peer
00658  *              address so we must ensure the port number is unique now.
00659  *              Allocations are done from the top of the namespace downward.
00660  *
00661  *              The two allocation methods track the extreme values used in each
00662  *              case to detect overlap, i.e., exhausted namespace. This can only
00663  *              happen if the number of connections supported is greater than the
00664  *              total namespace available.
00665  *
00666  * input parameters
00667  * @param   which   - Sending a link frame or a link reply frame
00668  * @param   newPtr  - pointer to connection info structure to be populated
00669  *
00670  * output parameters
00671  * @param   newPtr->portRx  - element is populated with port number.
00672  *
00673  * @return   Non-zero if port number assigned. 0 if no port available.
00674  */
00675 uint8_t nwk_allocateLocalRxPort(uint8_t which, connInfo_t *newPtr)
00676 {
00677 #if NUM_CONNECTIONS > 0
00678   uint8_t     num, i;
00679   uint8_t     marker[NUM_CONNECTIONS];
00680   connInfo_t *ptr = sPersistInfo.connStruct;
00681 
00682   memset(&marker, 0x0, sizeof(marker));
00683 
00684   for (i=0; i<NUM_CONNECTIONS; ++i,++ptr)
00685   {
00686     /* Mark the port number as used unless it's a statically allocated port */
00687     if ((ptr != newPtr) && (CONNSTATE_CONNECTED == ptr->connState) && (ptr->portRx <= SMPL_PORT_USER_MAX))
00688     {
00689       if (LINK_SEND == which)
00690       {
00691         if (ptr->portRx > sPersistInfo.curNextLinkPort)
00692         {
00693           marker[SMPL_PORT_USER_MAX - ptr->portRx] = 1;
00694         }
00695       }
00696       else if (!memcmp(ptr->peerAddr, newPtr->peerAddr, NET_ADDR_SIZE))
00697       {
00698           marker[ptr->portRx - PORT_BASE_NUMBER] = 1;
00699       }
00700     }
00701   }
00702 
00703   num = 0;
00704   for (i=0; i<NUM_CONNECTIONS; ++i)
00705   {
00706     if (!marker[i])
00707     {
00708       if (LINK_REPLY == which)
00709       {
00710         num = PORT_BASE_NUMBER + i;
00711       }
00712       else
00713       {
00714         num = SMPL_PORT_USER_MAX - i;
00715       }
00716       break;
00717     }
00718   }
00719 
00720   if (LINK_REPLY == which)
00721   {
00722     /* if the number we have doesn't overlap the assignment of ports used
00723      * for sending link frames, use it.
00724      */
00725     if (num <= sPersistInfo.curNextLinkPort)
00726     {
00727       if (num > sPersistInfo.curMaxReplyPort)
00728       {
00729         /* remember maximum port number used */
00730         sPersistInfo.curMaxReplyPort = num;
00731       }
00732     }
00733     else
00734     {
00735       /* the port number we need has already been used in the other context. It may or
00736        * may not have been used for the same address but we don't bother to check...we
00737        * just reject the asignment. This is the overly cautious part but is extermely
00738        * unlikely to ever occur.
00739        */
00740       num = 0;
00741     }
00742   }
00743   else
00744   {
00745     /* if the number we have doesn't overlap the assignment of ports used
00746      * for sending link frame replies, use it.
00747      */
00748     if (num >= sPersistInfo.curMaxReplyPort)
00749     {
00750       if (num == sPersistInfo.curNextLinkPort)
00751       {
00752         sPersistInfo.curNextLinkPort--;
00753       }
00754     }
00755     else
00756     {
00757       /* the port number we need has already been used in the other context. It may or
00758        * may not have been used for the same address but we don't bother to check...we
00759        * just reject the asignment. This is the overly cautious part but is extermely
00760        * unlikely to ever occur.
00761        */
00762       num = 0;
00763     }
00764   }
00765 
00766   newPtr->portRx = num;
00767 
00768   return num;
00769 #else
00770   return 0;
00771 #endif  /* NUM_CONNECTIONS > 0 */
00772 
00773 }
00774 
00775 /*******************************************************************************
00776  * @fn          nwk_isValidReply
00777  *
00778  * @brief       Examine a frame to see if it is a valid reply when compared with
00779  *              expected parameters.
00780  *
00781  * input parameters
00782  * @param   frame      - pointer to frmae being examined
00783  * @param   tid        - expected transaction ID in application payload
00784  * @param   infoOffset - offset to payload information containing reply hint
00785  * @param   tidOffset  - offset to transaction ID in payload
00786  *
00787  * output parameters
00788  *
00789  * @return   reply category:
00790  *               SMPL_NOT_REPLY: not a reply
00791  *               SMPL_MY_REPLY : a reply that matches input parameters
00792  *               SMPL_A_REPLY  : a reply but does not match input parameters
00793  */
00794 uint8_t nwk_isValidReply(mrfiPacket_t *frame, uint8_t tid, uint8_t infoOffset, uint8_t tidOffset)
00795 {
00796   uint8_t rc = SMPL_NOT_REPLY;
00797 
00798   if ((*(MRFI_P_PAYLOAD(frame)+F_APP_PAYLOAD_OS+infoOffset) & NWK_APP_REPLY_BIT))
00799   {
00800     if ((*(MRFI_P_PAYLOAD(frame)+F_APP_PAYLOAD_OS+tidOffset) == tid) &&
00801         !memcmp(MRFI_P_DST_ADDR(frame), nwk_getMyAddress(), NET_ADDR_SIZE))
00802     {
00803       rc = SMPL_MY_REPLY;
00804     }
00805     else
00806     {
00807       rc = SMPL_A_REPLY;
00808     }
00809   }
00810 
00811   return rc;
00812 }
00813 
00814 /******************************************************************************
00815  * @fn          map_lid2idx
00816  *
00817  * @brief       Map link ID to index into connection table.
00818  *
00819  * input parameters
00820  * @param   lid   - Link ID to be matched
00821  *
00822  * output parameters
00823  * @param   idx   - populated with index into connection table
00824  *
00825  * @return   Non-zero if Link ID found and output is valid else 0.
00826  */
00827 static uint8_t map_lid2idx(linkID_t lid, uint8_t *idx)
00828 {
00829   uint8_t     i;
00830   connInfo_t *ptr = sPersistInfo.connStruct;
00831 
00832   for (i=0; i<SYS_NUM_CONNECTIONS; ++i, ++ptr)
00833   {
00834     if ((CONNSTATE_CONNECTED == ptr->connState) && (ptr->thisLinkID == lid))
00835     {
00836       *idx = i;
00837       return 1;
00838     }
00839   }
00840 
00841   return 0;
00842 }
00843 
00844 /******************************************************************************
00845  * @fn          nwk_findPeer
00846  *
00847  * @brief       Find connection entry for a peer
00848  *
00849  * input parameters
00850  * @param   peerAddr   - address of peer
00851  * @param   peerPort   - port on which this device was sending to peer.
00852  *
00853  * output parameters
00854  *
00855  * @return   Pointer to matching connection table entry else 0.
00856  */
00857 connInfo_t *nwk_findPeer(addr_t *peerAddr, uint8_t peerPort)
00858 {
00859   uint8_t     i;
00860   connInfo_t *ptr = sPersistInfo.connStruct;
00861 
00862   for (i=0; i<SYS_NUM_CONNECTIONS; ++i, ++ptr)
00863   {
00864     if (CONNSTATE_CONNECTED == ptr->connState)
00865     {
00866       if (!memcmp(peerAddr, ptr->peerAddr, NET_ADDR_SIZE))
00867       {
00868         if (peerPort == ptr->portTx)
00869         {
00870           return ptr;
00871         }
00872       }
00873     }
00874   }
00875 
00876   return (connInfo_t *)NULL;
00877 }
00878 
00879 /******************************************************************************
00880  * @fn          nwk_checkAppMsgTID
00881  *
00882  * @brief       Compare received TID to last-seen TID to decide whether the
00883  *              received message is a duplicate or we missed some.
00884  *
00885  * input parameters
00886  * @param   lastTID   - last-seen TID
00887  * @param   appMsgTID - TID from current application payload.
00888  *
00889  * output parameters
00890  *
00891  * @return   Returns zero if message with supplied TID should be discarded.
00892  *           Otherwise returns non-zero. In this case the message should be
00893  *           processed. The last-seen TID should be updated with the current
00894  *           application payload TID.
00895  *
00896  */
00897 uint8_t nwk_checkAppMsgTID(appPTid_t lastTID, appPTid_t appMsgTID)
00898 {
00899   uint8_t rc = 0;
00900 
00901   /* If the values are equal this is a duplicate. We're done. */
00902   if (lastTID != appMsgTID)
00903   {
00904     /* Is the new TID bigger? */
00905     if (appMsgTID > lastTID)
00906     {
00907       /* In this case the current payload is OK unless we've received a late
00908        * (duplicate) message that occurred just before the TID wrapped. This is
00909        * considered a duplicate and we should discard it.
00910        */
00911       if (!(DUP_TID_AFTER_WRAP(lastTID, appMsgTID)))
00912       {
00913         rc = 1;
00914       }
00915     }
00916     else
00917     {
00918       /* New TID is smaller. Accept the payload if this is the wrap case or we missed
00919        * the specific wrap frame but are still within the range in which we assume
00920        * we missed it. Otherwise is a genuine late frame so we should ignore it.
00921        */
00922       if (CHECK_TID_WRAP(lastTID, appMsgTID))
00923       {
00924         rc = 1;
00925       }
00926     }
00927   }
00928 
00929   return rc;
00930 }
00931 
00932 /******************************************************************************
00933  * @fn          nwk_getNumObjectFromMsg
00934  *
00935  * @brief       Get a numeric object from a message buffer. Take care of
00936  *              alignment and endianess issues.
00937  *
00938  * input parameters
00939  * @param   src     - pointer to object location in message buffer
00940  * @param   objSize - size of numeric object
00941  *
00942  * output parameters
00943  * @param   dest - pointer to numeric type variable receiving the object
00944  *                 contains aligned number in correct endian order on return.
00945  *
00946  * @return   void. There is no warning if there is no case for the supplied
00947  *                 object size. A simple copy is then done. Alignment is
00948  *                 guaranteed only for object size cases defined (and
00949  *                 vacuously size 1).
00950  *
00951  */
00952 void nwk_getNumObjectFromMsg(void *src, void *dest, uint8_t objSize)
00953 {
00954   /* Take care of alignment */
00955   memmove(dest, src, objSize);
00956 
00957   /* Take care of endianess */
00958   switch(objSize)
00959   {
00960     case 2:
00961       *((uint16_t *)dest) = ntohs(*((uint16_t *)dest));
00962       break;
00963 
00964     case 4:
00965       *((uint32_t *)dest) = ntohl(*((uint32_t *)dest));
00966       break;
00967   }
00968 
00969   return;
00970 }
00971 
00972 /******************************************************************************
00973  * @fn          nwk_putNumObjectIntoMsg
00974  *
00975  * @brief       Put a numeric object into a message buffer. Take care of
00976  *              alignment and endianess issues.
00977  *
00978  * input parameters
00979  * @param   src     - pointer to numeric type variable providing the object
00980  * @param   objSize - size of numeric object. Fuction works for object size 1.
00981  *
00982  * output parameters
00983  * @param   dest - pointer to object location in message buffer where the
00984  *                 correct endian order representation will be placed.
00985  *
00986  * @return   void. There is no warning if there is no case for the supplied
00987  *                 object size. A simple copy is then done.
00988  *
00989  */
00990 void nwk_putNumObjectIntoMsg(void *src, void *dest, uint8_t objSize)
00991 {
00992 
00993   uint8_t *ptr;
00994   uint16_t u16;
00995   uint32_t u32;
00996 
00997   /* Take care of endianess */
00998   switch(objSize)
00999   {
01000     case 1:
01001       ptr = (uint8_t *)src;
01002       break;
01003 
01004     case 2:
01005       u16 = htons(*((uint16_t *)src));
01006       ptr = (uint8_t *)&u16;
01007       break;
01008 
01009     case 4:
01010       u32 = htonl(*((uint32_t *)src));
01011       ptr = (uint8_t *)&u32;
01012       break;
01013 
01014     default:
01015       ptr = (uint8_t *)src;
01016       break;
01017   }
01018 
01019   /* Take care of alignment */
01020   memmove(dest, ptr, objSize);
01021 
01022   return;
01023 }
01024 /******************************************************************************
01025  * @fn          nwk_NVObj
01026  *
01027  * @brief       GET and SET support for NV object (connection context).
01028  *
01029  * input parameters
01030  * @param   action  - GET or SET
01031  * @param   val     - (GET/SET) pointer to NV IOCTL object.
01032  *                    (SET) NV length and version values to be used for sanity
01033  *                    checks.
01034  *
01035  * output parameters
01036  * @param   val     - (GET) Version number of NV object, size of NV object and
01037  *                          pointer to the connection context memory.
01038  *                  - (SET) Pointer to the connection context memory.
01039  *
01040  * @return   SMPL_SUCCESS
01041  *           SMPL_BAD_PARAM   Object version or size do not conform on a SET call
01042  *                            or illegal action specified.
01043  */
01044 smplStatus_t nwk_NVObj(ioctlAction_t action, ioctlNVObj_t *val)
01045 {
01046 #ifdef NVOBJECT_SUPPORT
01047   smplStatus_t rc = SMPL_SUCCESS;
01048 
01049   if (IOCTL_ACT_GET == action)
01050   {
01051     /* Populate helper objects */
01052     val->objLen     = SIZEOF_NV_OBJ;
01053     val->objVersion = sPersistInfo.structureVersion;
01054     /* Set pointer to connection context if address of pointer is not null */
01055     if (val->objPtr)
01056     {
01057       *(val->objPtr) = (uint8_t *)&sPersistInfo;
01058     }
01059   }
01060   else
01061   {
01062     rc = SMPL_BAD_PARAM;
01063   }
01064 
01065   return rc;
01066 #else  /* NVOBJECT_SUPPORT */
01067   return SMPL_BAD_PARAM;
01068 #endif
01069 }
